loans.name: Affiavi

texts.fr: H. Affiavi est née le 02 Avril 1976 à Athièmè, à proximité de la frontière du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Affiavi est mariée à TOSSOUVI Albert, un conducteur d’engins lourds, et est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Affiavi vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants à Hêdomey à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis 5 ans. C’est depuis 4 ans que Affiavi mène comme activité, la vente de maïs, haricot, riz et de « sodabi » (boisson alcoolisée locale), à son domicile. Affiavi achète ses produits à Adja au Mono au Bénin, et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Affiavi a déjà obtenu un crédit de ALIDé qu’elle a bien remboursé. C’est pour agrandir son activité et répondre mieux à la demande de la clientèle que Affiavi sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Affiavi was born on April 2, 1976 in Athièmè, near the border of Togo, a country neighboring Benin.  She is married to TOSSOUVI Albert, a big rig driver, and she is the mother of four children who are all in school.  For five years, she has been living with her husband and children in Hêdomey in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  For four years, Affiavi has been running a business selling corn, beans rice, and sodabi (a local alcoholic drink) out of her home.  She buys her goods in Adja in Mono, in Benin, and at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has had an ALIDé loan before, which she repaid.  To expand her business and to respond better to customer demands, she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, a sack of beans, 2 drums of "sodabi"

loans.name: Onome

texts.en:
Onome lives in Edo State, Nigeria, where she sells groceries, drinks, fruit and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. With her combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her immediate family members.

Onome is 49 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a commercial tailor. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

Onome is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more fruit, drinks and groceries to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, drinks and fruit to sell

loans.name: Particia

texts.en:
Patricia is a 50-year-old married woman with two children aged 15 and 23 years. Both of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she lives with four people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Patricia has a retail shop selling all household essentials. She works seven days a week in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She serves an average of ten customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She incurs transport costs to and from shopping from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala city. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever-increasing prices of essentials in Uganda.

Patricia has been in her business for over five years and with MCDT also for five years. She is servicing her tenth loan. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with it. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her retail shop. She aspires to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Lapiniye

texts.en:
Lapiniye G. is currently in the business of selling dried fish in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase onions and cooking oil to sell. Lapiniye is a 45-year-old widow. She has seven children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Kasanda

texts.en:
Kasanda M. is an entrepreneur and a married Tanzanian businessman with one primary school child. He runs a barber shop at Buguruni District in Dar es Salaam.

Business requirements are purchased from the wholesale cosmetics shop at Kariakoo city business shopping center. Kasanda has been in the business for three years and his business income is used to capitalize his business and meet his family’s daily needs.

Kasanda is requesting a loan of Tsh 800,000 to boost his business.

loans.use: To boost his business

loans.name: Estelle Evelyne Yelian

texts.fr: M. Estelle Evelyne Yelian est née le 09 Février 1987 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Estelle Evelyne Yelian est une célibataire résidant depuis plus d’un an à Cococodji, non loin de Cotonou. Estelle Evelyne Yelian vit seule et n’a pas encore d’enfant. Estelle Evelyne Yelian a arrêté l’école au cours primaire. Il y a de cela 1 an 6 mois que  Estelle Evelyne Yelian vend du maïs en gros et en détail au marché de Cococodji, afin de subvenir à ses besoins. Estelle Evelyne Yelian s’approvisionne à Azovè et à Dogbo, deux marché de produits vivriers au Bénin. Estelle Evelyne Yelian n’a jamais obtenu de crédit à ALIDé. Pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et accroître son activité, Estelle Evelyne Yelian sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
M. Estelle Evelyne Yelian was born on February 9, 1987 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is unmarried and has been residing for over a year in Cococodji, not far from Cotonou. She lives alone and has no children yet. She stopped attending primary school. A year and six months later, she started selling corn wholesale and retail at the Cococodji market in order to support herself. She stocks up in Azovè and in Dogbo, two markets for staple foods in Benin. Estelle Evelyne Yelian has never had an ALIDé before. To augment her working capital and to grow her business, she's requesting a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 sacks of corn

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 60 years old and married with a child. Her husband is an engineer. She sells fish at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to be a major fish distributor in the future. She is a focused hard worker. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more fish to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Hondohondo Group

texts.en:
Rizki M. is married but doesn't have children – "yet", he stresses! He currently owns a mitumba shop selling secondhand clothing, shoes, handbags, etc. He started this business in 2006 and makes a monthly profit of about $120 which he uses to support himself and his wife. He keeps his shop in the Kiwalani district of Dar es Salaam. It is open from 8:30 am to 10:00 pm daily. This is Rizki's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He wants to use his loan to increase his stock and he hopes to invest in better quality used clothing and accessories. 

In the picture, Rizki is on the far left wearing a white shirt. Rizki will share this loan with the members of his group, "Hondohondo". The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing and accessories to resell

loans.name: Please Clear Group

texts.en:
Sheila O. is 27 years old and is unmarried. She has two children that she supports on her own: a daughter and a son, seven and five years old.

Sheila's business is raising chicks and selling them when they are about eight weeks old. She buys the "vifaranga" (“chicks" in Kiswahili) when they are very small, and then sells them for about $3 per chicken when they have grown. She started this business very recently and has only just begun to sell the older chickens.

Sheila runs her business from her home, and she says that people come at all times of the day and night to buy her chickens. Her monthly profit will vary a lot, she says, because chicks sometimes die of diseases or cannot be sold when they are older because they look unhealthy. She estimates that in the first month of business she made a profit of about $300.

Sheila hopes to use this loan to buy more chicks and chicken feed to expand her business. She will share the loan with the members of her subgroup C of Agano, and subgroup B of the same larger group. The members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

The members of the group have a variety of businesses. Three of them are tailors, two have beauty salons, one sells charcoal, and the rest sell food. In the photo, Sheila is wearing a pink shirt and is standing in the back row.

loans.use: To buy more chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is a 35-year-old married woman with four children between 4 and 12 years old. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a three-roomed house where she lives with five people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Prossy works seven days a week in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She has a ladies’ salon in Kibuye on the Kampala-Entebbe highway. She receives an average of seven customers a day and sells to all categories of people She also sells creams to her customers. She incurs transport costs to and from shopping in Kikuubo, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever-increasing prices of hair conditioners and hair extensions.

Besides this banana business she also sells beer at her home.

Prossy has been in this business for over seven years and with MCDT for eight years. She is servicing her twentieth loan. Prossy joined MCDT because it was near her home. She wants to use this loan to buy more hair extensions and conditioners.

loans.use: To buy more hair extensions and hair conditioners

loans.name: Dira Group

texts.en:
Flora M. is 30 years old. She is unmarried but has a daughter who is 12. Flora runs a "vipodozi", which means "pharmacy" in Kiswahili. Unlike some other pharmacies in Dar es Salaam, Flora also sells beauty care products like soap and shampoo along with regular medicines. 

She opened her business last year, and keeps the store open from 8 am to 10 pm daily. Her profits vary by month, she says, but she estimates that her profits range from $225-$340 per month. 

This is Flora's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first to increase the inventory at her business, and she paid the loan back successfully with no late payments. She hopes to use this loan to increase her stock of medicines, soaps, and hair products.

In the photo, Flora is sitting on the bench wearing a green dress. She and the members of her group, Dira, will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more medicines, soaps and hair products to sell.

loans.name: Iyobosa

texts.en:
Iyobosa is 42 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a carpenter. She sells groceries, drinks and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for her business, and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers.

She is a friendly woman who is determined to excel in all that she lays her hand to do. She started her business this year.

She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Carot Group

texts.en:
Isabella I., age 25, is unmarried. She has a daughter who is three years old named Beatrice. Isabella owns and operates a beauty salon in the Tegeta area of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. She has been working in the beauty salon business since 2003, beginning when she was just 19!

The salon is open from 8:30 am until 9 pm daily, and Isabella makes a monthly profit of about $250. This is her second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. The first loan was repaid successfully and helped Isabella to maintain her salon.

With this loan, she hopes to invest in salon equipment like scissors and combs, hair weaves, shampoos and conditioners, and other products to increase the operating capacity of the salon. In the picture, Isabella is in the back row wearing red. Isabella will share this loan with the members of her group, Carot. They will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: Salon equipment, hair weaves, and hair products for her salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of maize in bulk.

loans.name: White Group

texts.en:
Methew A., age 35, is married with two children, ages 11 and 9. He also cares for his younger brother's son, who is 12. He has had a general store since 2001. He works daily from 6:30 am until 11 pm, making a monthly profit of about $267.

This will be Methew's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He will use this loan to increase the stock of his general store, buying more items like sugar, wheat, flour, cooking oil, mosquito sprays, and fabrics.

Methew will share this loan with subgroup D of the White group. The subgroup has seven members, who run groceries, general stores like Methew's, and work as food vendors. These members will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, Methew is the first on the left.

loans.use: To buy stock for Methew's general store

loans.name: Cathérine

texts.fr: D. Cathérine est née le 20 Avril 1966 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à AGBONGBE Célestin, un  employé à l’entreprise Colas au Bénin, Cathérine est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Cathérine a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. C’est depuis 6 ans que Cathérine vit à Hèdomey à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou. En effet, Cathérine vit avec ses enfants et son conjoint, et vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Cathérine n’a jamais été à l’école ; il y a deux ans déjà que Cathérine vend de la friperie au marché de Cococodji et de façon ambulante à Dantokpa marché international du Bénin. Cathérine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa et à Missèbo à Cotonou, un marché de friperie au Bénin. Cathérine a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Pour étendre l’écoulement de sa marchandise sur d’autres marchés du Bénin, Cathérine sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Cathérine D. was born on April 20, 1966 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Célestin Agbongbe, an employee of Colas in Benin, Cathérine is the mother of two children who are both in school. Cathérine also has another child in her care, in addition to her own two children. Cathérine has lived in Hédomey in Cocotomey, which is not far from Cotonou, for six years. Cathérine lives with her children and her spouse, and helps him take care of the family's expenses. Cathérine never went to school. For two years, Cathérine has sold second-hand clothes at the Cococodji market and as a traveling vendor at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Cathérine gets her stock at Dantokpa and Missèbo in Cotonou, the latter a second-hand clothing market in Benin. Cathérine has already obtained a loan from Alidé and repaid it in full. Cathérine is requesting a second loan through Alidé so she can sell her merchandise in even more markets in Benin.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of two bundles of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 29 years old. She is divorced with three kids. Her kids are in school. She lives with her family in a community in the western region of Ghana. As a single mother, all the family responsibilities rest on her shoulders. 

She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. She is very skillful and a talented hair dresser. With her five years of experience, she has lots of clients. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like assorted wigs, pomade, shampoo, activators, hair dryer machines, etc. to serve her customers well. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of hair products like wigs, pomade, shampoo, activators etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business by adding a variety of goods.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 39 years old; she is married and has seven children. She is committed and a very hard-working lady. She believes in assisting her husband in running the home financially and otherwise. 

Mary is into poultry farming. She has been in the poultry business for years and with it she sustains her family. She buys her stock from the local market and sells to her customers. Most of the challenges she faces in her chicken business is when she purchases sick chickens without knowing it and the transportation costs, which are very high in the area. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more chickens and poultry feed. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens and feed

loans.name: Manuel Dejesus

texts.en:
Manuel is 23 years old. He is married to Esther, who is 22 years old and they live in Ita. 
Today Manuel has a sewing and tailoring business, but his beginnings were very difficult. When he graduated from his studies in industrial manufacturing, Manuel had no working capital to start his own business. He had to work as a driver in a building materials warehouse to save some money. He saved up enough to open a sewing workshop.

The demand for garment making has been increasing, which is why Manuel requires a new sewing machine, so that he can continue to work hard and dedicate his life to his business. 
Manuel knows that the loan represents working capital and the invaluable benefit it will bring to increasing his and his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: A sewing machine

loans.name: Obama Group

texts.en:
Domini K., age 34, is married with three children, ages 15, 5, and 1 year old. She is a tailor, selling tailoring equipment, sarongs, materials, fabrics, and handmade clothing since 2000. She works daily from 8 a.m. until 9 p.m., managing to make a monthly profit of around $267.

This will be Domini's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to expand her tailoring business and repaid the loan successfully. She hopes this loan will help her make her business even larger and more successful. She will use the extra capital to invest in more fabrics and tailoring equipment.

Domini will share this loan with her loan group, Obama, which totals 16 members. In the picture, Domini is first on the left front row, sitting on the blue chair.

loans.use: Buying more fabric for the tailoring shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional goods for her duka business.

loans.name: Blásida

texts.en:
Blásida is 21 years old and is married to Cirilo, who is 20 years old. She lives in Ita, where she has been a professional saleswoman at a pantry for more than two years. She works to improve the quality of life for her family. She hopes to expand her business and increase her income to sustain her family. 

Blásida plans to use the loan to invest in her business by purchasing milk, candy, meat, noodles, beer, soft drinks, sausages, vegetables and others products. “These products would help me improve the products I can offer by having greater variety and getting a better flow of customers, “ says Blásida. 

She is grateful for the opportunity to have access to a loan, because it will increase her merchandise sales and thus increase her income for the welfare of her entire family.

loans.use: To buy food for sale.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet sells groceries, drinks and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers in Benin City, Edo state. This is the high season for her business, and she hopes to make more profit during this season. She is 42 years old and married with two children. She hopes to give her children a quality education. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more drinks, groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and containers for her ice cream business.

loans.name: Immaculée Amédée

texts.fr: W. Immaculée Amédée est née le 02 Décembre 1969 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Immaculée Amédée est mariée à DJAGA Anatole un commerçant. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C’est Anatole qui supporte les charges de la famille. Immaculée Amédée s’est arrêtée au cours primaire à l’école, et depuis deux ans, elle vend des divers (pâtes alimentaires, savons, pommades, papier hygiénique, lait, conserves, sardine, bougies, etc.) dans sa boutique. Immaculée Amédée vend également des liqueurs dans sa boutique. Immaculée Amédée s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Immaculée Amédée a déjà obtenu auprès de ALIDé un crédit qui a été bien remboursé. En vue d’agrandir sa boutique et de satisfaire davantage la demande de sa clientèle, Immaculée Amédée sollicite auprès de ALIDé un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Immaculée Amédée W. was born on December 2, 1969 in Ouidah, a historic city in Benin. Immaculée Amédée is married to Anatole Djaga, a vendor. The couple has two children who are both in school. Anatole takes care of the family's expenses. Immaculée Amédée dropped out of elementary school, and for the past two years she has sold various items (pasta, soap, ointment, toilet paper, milk, canned goods, sardines, candles, etc.) in her shop. Immaculée Amédée also sells liqueurs in her boutique. She gets her stock at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has already received one loan through Alidé which she repaid in full. Immaculée Amédée is requesting a second loan through Alidé to increase the size of her boutique and to better meet her customer demand.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items (4 boxes of soap, 3 boxes of prepackaged sugar, 6 boxes of bottled liqueur)

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo is 25 years old, was born in Asuncion, and lives 29 km from the capital in a neighborhood known as Guarambaré City with his father and sister. He operates a pantry with his sister, Carmen, that he inherited from his mother five years ago. It is popular among their neighbors and they sell sugar, rice, beverages, dairy and other food staples for the home.

The loan sought is for the purchase of a freezer. With summer approaching, there will be greater demand for cold drinks. Eduardo would also like to invest in the purchase of various goods such as rice, sugar, coal, etc. Eduardo has worked with Fundacion Paraguaya for three years and has always repaid his loans on time.

loans.use: Freezer, foodstuffs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase hair products, shampoo and other materials for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam M. N. is a married, Tanzanian, small-business woman with three school children. She runs a foodstuffs shop at Yombo Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of foodstuffs including maize flour, wheat flour, beans, sugar and cooking oil.

Mariam purchases her business goods from the wholesale shops and from the foodstuffs suppliers. She has been in the business for seven years and she needs a loan of Tsh 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 40 years old, married with four children. She sells baby things and colorful sarongs. With the combined businesses, she is able to meet her family’s basic needs and other necessities.  

She has been in this business for five years. She is requesting a loan amount of 70,000 Nigerian naira (NGN) to purchase baby things and sarongs to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers.

She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby things and sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 61 years old. She is married and the mother of ten children. All her children are grown up except her last born, who is still in school. Her husband is a farmer in the community where they live. She works hard to support her husband in providing for the house. 

Grace prepares and bakes bread and runs a grocery shop. She has run both concurrently for seventeen years now. In spite of the challenges she faces, it is her bread and the grocery business that generates an income to support the home. 

Grace takes delivery of stock from Kumasi and sells retail to her customers. She also has customers who come to her to buy in bulk. She bakes in bulk and her customers order from her to sell baked goods with their beverages and other things. 

Her only problem now has to do with adequate funds to buy raw materials to meet her demand. She requests a loan to remain in business and would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy baking materials like bags of flour, sugar, margarine, yeast, and firewood.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria U. is 54 years old. She is married and has seven children.

Maria owns a poultry farm and a shop where she sells food stuffs. Maria has been in these businesses for some years. She manages these businesses to support her husband, who is a retired army officer. Maria is a LAPO client; she has been in LAPO for six years.

Maria is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira (NGN) in order to purchase more food stuffs and feed in bulk, as this attracts customers and increases her profit. With this, she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to better provide for her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase more food stuffs and chicken feed.

loans.name: Ramón

texts.en:
Ramón N. is 43 years old and lives in the village of J. Augusto Saldivar, a few miles from Asuncion.

Ramón has two trucks, one of which he uses for the transportation of fruit and vegetables to sell at farmer’s markets, supermarkets, meat markets, and shops in the neighborhoods of Asunción and surrounding areas. He has been delivering fruit and vegetables for more than 15 years. With the other truck, Ramón moves freight and make other large deliveries. He has been in that business for over 4 years.

Ramón started his business with a horse-drawn cart in a busy neighborhood. After working hard for many years, he saved the money necessary to replace his horse and cart with a truck. Ramón also has 33 hectares of land, which he received as an inheritance from his parents. There, Ramón plants vegetables, which he also then harvests and sells from his truck. 

Ramón needs a loan so that he can repair his truck, an indispensable part of his business.

loans.use: To repair his delivery truck.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank is a 42-year old trader. He is married and the father of three children. All his children are currently in school. He has been struggling to provide the needs of his children's education and that has been his greatest challenge. In spite of that, he tries hard to provide for their education and pay all of his bills. 

Frank supports his family through the sale of used clothing and bed sheets. Frank has been in this business for the past ten years. In Ghana, brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor, so used clothing and bed sheets have a very big market share. Frank usually concentrates on kids' wear, bed sheets and used towels. He travels to a nearby city called Kumasi to purchase his stock of goods. 

Frank wants to use this loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase his inventory. He believes this loan would help him save for his children's future and also help him to rent a store to trade in, as right now he sells through hawking.

loans.use: To buy increased bales of used clothing for resale.

loans.name: Amélé

texts.fr: M. Amélé est née en 1974 à Lomé, capitale du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Amélé est mariée à GLAHOU Laurent, un entrepreneur. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C’est depuis trois ans que Amélé vit avec ses enfants et son conjoint à Cocotomey, non de loin de Cotonou capitale économique du Bénin. Amélé vient en aide à son mari Laurent dans les charges de la famille. Amélé n’a jamais été à l’école. Amélé a abandonné la vente de nourriture (pâte de maïs fermenté) au profit de la vente de sacs de charbon de bois et de sacs de maïs à son domicile et aussi par le système de distribution. Amélé achète ses produits dans le Nord du Bénin. Amélé a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Amélé voudrait aller dans le Nord du Bénin afin de s’approvisionner en gros et d’agrandir son activité. C’est pourquoi Amélé sollicite un deuxième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Amélé M. was born in 1974 in Lomé, the capital of Togo, which borders Benin. Amélé is married to Laurent Glahou, an entrepreneur. The couple has four children who are all in school. For the past three years, Amélé has lived with her children and husband in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Amélé helps her husband Laurent handle the family's expenses. Amélé never went to school. Amélé stopped selling food items (ogi, a fermented cereal porridge) and began selling sacks of charcoal and corn at home and also through the distribution system. Amélé buys her stock in northern Benin. She has already received one loan through Alidé which she repaid in full. She is requesting a second loan through Alidé because she would like to travel to northern Benin to buy her stock wholesale and therefore improve her business

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 6 sacks of charcoal and 4 sacks of corn

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes E. is 49 years old and married with seven children.

Agnes sells groceries and drinks in order to meet her immediate family's basic needs and other necessities. She has been in this business for five years. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira (NGN) to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. 

She thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is 23 years old. He is married with two children. 

Thomas has been a professional carpenter for the past five years. Carpentry has been his major occupation and the main source of livelihood for his family. He owns a carpentry shop where he manufactures all kinds of furniture. 

Thomas says that for lack of adequate working capital, he is not able to pre-finance most of the orders from his customers. This slows down his work because he necessarily has to wait for funds from his customers before any work can begin. Most often, this delays work.

Thomas requests the loan to enable him to procure useful working tools and furnishing materials like polish, glue, sandpaper, and wood in order to improve his efficiency. He believes this will improve his income status and help ensure a good living for his family. He would be grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To procure useful working tools and furnishing materials like polish, glue, sandpaper, and wood.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya est  composé de cinq  femmes dont, une veuve et quatre mariées dans des ménages monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 50 ans, 5 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Bagadadji de la ville de Ségou  (4ème Région administrative du Mali)
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, professionnel  et exercent essentiellement  le commerce d’articles divers.
Après avoir correctement remboursé, les cinq prêts précédents, elles sont à leur 6ème  prêt solidaire qu’elles comptent utiliser pour acheter,  10 pièces de pagnes wax, 4 tenues en tissus brodés, 10 draps de lit, 5 tenues en cotonnade pour homme (Faso danfani,) 20 tenues en bazin de 5 m chacune, des produits nécessaires à la teinture, 3 tonnes de charbon de bois,1 chargement de camion en bois de chauffe, 15 sacs d’arachide en gousse et des ingrédients de l’encens (10kg de sarkatanè, 2kg de magnonkissè horon, 5 flacons d’eau de Cologne et 10 flacons de parfums .  
Elles s’approvisionnent en pagnes wax, tenues en tissus brodés, tenues en cotonnade pour homme « Faso danfani »et draps de lit une fois par mois à Lomé, Guinée Conakry et Burkina Faso, en bazins, produits de teinture  à Bamako, le bois de chauffe et le charbon de bois sont fournis par des transporteurs venant de Konobougou, l’arachide et les ingrédients pour l’encens est acheté au marché Château  avec les forains de Loulouni et de Koutiala. Actuellement avec l’approche de la fête les lieux d’approvisionnements et de ventes se multiplient. 
Les habits et l’encens sont vendus sur commande à Sikasso, Dioïla et à Macina, en ambulant à travers les quartiers d’Angoulême et de Bagadadji, le bois et le charbon sont vendus en demi gros et en détail à domicile, l’arachide est vendu à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou et au marché de Ségou Coura. Les ventes se font au comptant, en détail, en demi gros et  à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles  comptent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 62.500 FCFA qui servira à rembourser le prêt,  les tontines, à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux, assurer les frais de nourriture et de déplacement des enfants étudiant à Bamako, à participer aux évènements sociaux. 
Leurs ambitions se résument à pérenniser leurs activités commerciales et assurer la formation et l’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The Danaya group is composed of five women, one widowed and four in monogamous marriages. They are 50-years-old on average, have 5 children, and live in the Bagadadji quarter of Segou village (the 4th administrative region of Mali).They know each other through neighbors, are professional, and work trading miscellaneous articles. After having paid back their last 5 loans, they are together for their sixth loan. They plan on using it to buy 10 pieces of waxed cloth, 4 embroidered dress fabrics, 10 bed sheets, 5 cotton suits for men (Faso danfani), 20 5-meter damasque fabrics, products for dying, 3 tons of wood charcoal, 1 truckload of firewood, 15 sacks of unshelled peanuts, and supplies to make incense. They buy the cloth and linens in bulk once a month in Lomé, Guinée Conakry and Burkina Faso while they purchase the damasque fabric and dye products in Bamako; the firewood and charcoal are provided by transporters from Konobougou. The peanuts and the incense supplies are bought at the Chateau market at Loulouni and Koutiala's stalls. Now, with the holidays approaching, provisions and sales are increasing. They sell the clothing and incense in Sikasso, Dioila, and Macina, traveling across the Angouleme and Bagadadji regions, while the wood and charcoal are sold to households and the peanuts are sold at the weekly fair in Segou and at the Segou Coura Market. Sales, both wholesale and retail, are made in cash and credit to male and female customers. They expect an average monthly profit of 62,500 FCFA. This profit will repay the loan and the tontines, fulfill their small family needs, assure fresh food, pay for their children's travels to study in Bamako, and finance participation in social events. Their ambitious hard work continues to make their commercial activities profitable and assure the health and education of their children.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers. - Buying of miscellaneous items

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther I. and her husband sell motor spare parts at retail prices. 

Esther is 33 years old, married with five children. All her children are doing well in school. She hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira (NGN) to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. 

She is a focused, hard worker and she is so happy with this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. 

She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena is 50 years old. She is married to Mr. N. who is a civil servant and they have eight children.

Philomena sells groceries and drinks and does this trade to make her living; she manages the business with her last two children who are in school. Philomena intends to add other items like fresh fish, vegetables, etc., to her sales as the level of demand for them is high. This will attract sales and maximize her profit.

Philomena’s challenge is power failure. She is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase a generator that will power her freezer and other electrical appliances at the shop.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and a generator

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence has been selling cereals like maize and eggs to her loyal customers in the community market. She is the 38-year-old mother of four children. All her children are in school except for her last born who is still breastfeeding. She takes delivery of goods from Techiman, in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She says selling these products is very lucrative and, with her six years of sales experience, she believes her dream of expanding her business will come true. She will use this loan to increase her inventory so she can make a good income to support her family, especially their education.

Florence would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals like groundnuts and beans

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a food vendor. She sells fried yam and raw yam by the road in Juaboso, where she lives in the western region of Ghana. She fries the yam and arranges it in a glass showcase to attract customers to buy. Fried yam is enjoyed with hot pepper in the mornings, afternoons and evenings. Mary is 30 years old, married and the mother of a child who is currently in school. She works hard to support her husband so that they can take care of the home. Mary travels to Techiman to buy her stock of goods (especially the yam). She does this to prevent intermediaries from selling to her at higher prices. She is requesting this loan so she can buy stock in bulk and reduce frequent traveling.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of yam, vegetables, firewood, cooking oil and fresh fish, etc.

loans.name: Nyetaa Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Nyetaa est composé de quatre femmes,  mariées majoritairement dans des ménages polygames. Elles ont  en moyenne   38 ans, 5 enfants et habitent au Camp Militaire de Ségou  (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage car sont toutes épouses de militaires et font partie de la même association Finesse d’entre aide des femmes du camp. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers.
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, elles sont à leur prêt  solidaire.
Elles comptent acheter, 10 tenues en bazins moins riche, 15 pièces de pagnes wax, 6 tenues en tissus brodés, 2 sacs de farine de blé, 2 bidons  d’huile alimentaires de 20Litres et des ingrédients pour la fabrication de l’encens. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en habits à Bamako et au grand marché de Ségou, en ingrédients pour l’encens, les pagnes en wax, l’huile, la farine au grand marché de Ségou.  
Les habits  sont vendus   au grand marché, à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou et au marché château et à l’intérieur du camp, l’encens est repartie en deux une partie est vendue au grand marché et l’autre est donnée à crédit aux femmes du camp sur commande, les beignets en farine de blé   sont vendu au marché de Ségou Coro.  Les ventes se font   au comptant et  à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 27.375 FCFA qui servira à rembourser le prêt,  les tontines, à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux,  à participer aux événements sociaux, à acheter de petits ruminants. 
Elles ambitionnent avoir une maison à usage d’habitation à Ségou ou Bamako.
texts.en:
The group Nyetaa is composed of four married women mostly in polygamous households.  The women average 38 years of age and five children each and live at the Camp Militaire de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through community ties because they are all the wives of soldiers and belong to the same association "Finesse", a women's mutual-aid organization of the camp.  The group members do commerce in a variety of goods. Concerned about satisfying customer needs, they decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their solidarity loan.  They intend to buy ten outfits of moins riche damask outfits, fifteen bolts of Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), six outfits of embroidered cloth, two sacks of wheat flour, two 20-liter containers of cooking oil, and some ingredients for making incense.  Supplies of clothing are gotten in Bamako and at the big market of Ségou;  ingredients for incense, pagnes, oil, and flour are gotten at the big market of Ségou.  The clothing is sold at the big market, at the weekly fair in Ségou, at the Château market, and inside the camp.  The incense are divided into two, with one part sold at the big market and the other part lent out to the women in the camp by special order.  The beignets made of wheat flour are sold at the Ségou Coro market to customers composed of women and men. The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 27,375 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan and the lending association, to meet sundry family needs, to assist with societal events, and to buy small ruminants.  Their ambition is to have a house in which to live in Ségou or Bamako.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fruit (3 baskets of pineapples, 2 truck-loads of oranges) and 10 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience sells groceries and drinks. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is an energetic woman and she is optimistic about the growth of her business. Patience is 38 years old and happily married. Her husband is a trader. They live in Edo State, Nigeria.

Patience hopes to make more profit during this high season. She applied for a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a 32-year-old divorced mother of three children, all currently in school. She sponsors the children's education, health care, food, etc. by herself through her cake-baking business, which she has operated for about a year. She acquired her baking skills from her late aunt. In addition to supplying her regular customers, Mercy sells through hawking in the community market where she lives.

Because she promotes good customer relations, she has many customers; she is now requesting loan to procure additional stock such as flour, flavor, nut milk, eggs, baking powder etc. Mercy believes sales will increase as we enter Christmas, and she would be grateful for the assistance Kiva lenders can provide.

loans.use: To buy items like flour, flavor, nut milk, eggs, baking powder etc.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.fr:
Madame Hawa Kouyaté a 36 ans et réside avec son époux et leurs deux  enfants dans une famille nucléaire à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Hawa, après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à l’activité d’achat et  de vente des  friperies il y a environ six ans. Elle mène cette activité à son domicile et de façon ambulante dans la ville de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus 1 an, avec laquelle elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel. Le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 12 pièces de pagne wax, 10 complets de tissus brodés et 15 paires de chaussures différentes. 
Elle achète les chaussures, les tissus brodés et les pagnes wax à  Bamako et à Bobo Dioulasso  avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Hawa Kouyaté is 36 years old and resides with her husband and their children in a nuclear family in Hamdallaye, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After having run many businesses unsuccessfully, she was introduced to the business of buying and selling second-hand clothing about six years ago. She operates out of her home and from place to place in Sikasso City, where she is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her goods.  To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over a year ago.  She is now on her second individual loan.  The previous one was properly repaid.   She intends to use this loan to buy 12 bolts of Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), 10 suits of embroidered fabrics, and 15 pairs of various shoes.  She purchases her supplies of shoes, embroidered fabrics, and pagnes in Bamako and in Bobo Dioulasso and then sells them retail, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed essentially of women.   With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for augmenting her working capital, helping to cover family expenses, and paying the interest on her loan. The rest will be invested into her business.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy "pagne" cloth, choes, and embroidered fabrics

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa is 42 years old and is a local restaurant operator. She is widowed and has four kids and all are currently in school.

Adwoa prepares and sells local food like fufu with bush meat. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, taken with all kinds of soup. With her tasty meals she has attracted lots of customers in the area she serves. Therefore it has become necessary to employ additional hands to assist her in her food-delivering service. That was when we visited her at her local restaurant.

Adwoa says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures. With the loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials like baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood to prepare her meals. She would be grateful for that assistance.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for preparing her meals

loans.name: Kadidia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadidia B. a 30 ans, mariée et  mère de deux enfant elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I- Kapel Kourou, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Kadidia après avoir mené beaucoup d’activité sans succès, s’est initiée à l’activité d’achat et de  vente d’huiles alimentaires, de couscous arabe et  de cube maggie  il y a environ sept ans. 
Elle mène son activité à la maison et au marché de son quartier où elle dispose  d’une place. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. Elle est actuellement à son 2ème prêt individuel et le précédent a été bien remboursé.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 6 bidons d’huiles alimentaires, 2 cartons de couscous arabe et 4 cartons de cubes maggies. 
Elle  achète ses marchandises sur commande à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) et aussi dans les huileries de place avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit au marché de son quartier ,à une clientèle composée des femmes. .
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Kadidia B., aged 30, is married and the mother of two children.  She lives with her husband and their children in Sanoubougou I- Kapel Kourou, an outlying district of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After having run many businesses unsuccessfully, she got introduced to the business of buying and selling cooking oils, Arabian couscous, and Maggie bouillon cubes about seven years ago.  She operates at her house and at the market in her district, where she has a spot.  She is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her goods.  To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago.  She is now on her second individual loan.  The preceding one has been repaid.  With this loan, she intends to buy 6 containers of cooking oil, 2 boxes of Arabian couscous, and 4 boxes of Maggie cubes.   Supplies of these goods are gotten by special order from Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and also from local oil producers.  She then sells at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of women at the district marketplace. With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.  The rest will be invested into the business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery items to sell

loans.name: Isioma

texts.en: Isioma, a 40-year-old mother of five children and wife of Mr. A., a civil servant, sells foodstuffs and drinks, a business that enables her to support her family's basic needs and necessities. With her loan request of N100,000, Isioma plans to expand her business, which is now booming. She hopes to increase her earnings in the long term and be able to better provide for her children's education.  The greatest challenge she faces in her business is power failures.  She and her family say thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator for the business

loans.name: Philo

texts.en: Philo is 28 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial motorcyclist. She is a hair stylist and she also sells hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. She is happy because the high season is here and her sales will increase. Philo lives in Edo State, Nigeria and is hoping for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions to sell to her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Salif Y.  a 51 ans, polygame et père de sept  enfants. Il réside avec ses deux femmes et ses enfants dans sa propre maison à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école et après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, il s’est vite initié aux activités commerciales notamment à l’achat-vente des appareils électroniques (radios, cassette (K7), panneaux Satellitaires, Batteries, Antennes Paraboliques, téléphones portables et divers) il y a maintenant plus de 20 ans. 
Avec une si grande expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes, mais les ressources financières nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins font défaut. 
Ainsi, il sollicite ce 3ème prêt individuel  auprès de Soro Yiriwaso qui lui permettra d’acheter, 20 radios de marques différentes, 7 panneaux satellitaires, 3 batteries blindées, 8 antennes paraboliques et 180 cassettes. 
Il  s’approvisionne à Bamako pour venir les revendre à Sikasso dans sa boutique à la gare routière à côté de la compagnie Kènèdougou Voyage. Il a pour clients potentiels les voyageurs, les routiers , même d’autres qui sont sur place c’est à dire  vivant dans la ville de Sikasso. Ses ventes se font au comptant comme à crédit.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité principale.
texts.en:
Mr. Salif Y., aged 51, is a polygamist and the father of seven children. He lives with his two wives and his children in his own house in Sanoubougou I, one of the working-class neighborhoods of Sikasso in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

He didn't have the chance to attend school and after having tried several activities without success, he finally initiated himself into commercial activities and began a business trading in electronic appliances (radio sets, cassette recorders, satellite dishes, batteries, dish antennas, cell phones and similar products). That was over 20 years ago. Today he has gained such an experience in his trade that he enjoys a solid reputation among his customers and attracts a lot of orders, but he lacks the financial resources to fully meet this demand.

This is why he came to Soro Yiriwaso and applied for his third individual loan. He will use it to buy 20 radio sets of various brands, 7 satellite dishes, 3 armor-plated batteries, 8 dish antennas and 180 tape cassettes. He gets his supplies in Bamako and brings them to his store in Sikasso, which is located at the bus station, right next to the office of the travel company Kènèdougou Voyage. His potential customers are travelers, carriers and even other people around his place, i.e. residents of Sikasso. He sells for cash and credit.

Thanks to this loan Salif expects to make a monthly profit of 200,000 CFA francs, which will be enough to pay for most of his expenses, those of his family and the interest payments of his loan. He will reinvest the remaining amounts in his business.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electronic appliances and accessories

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a hair stylist and she also sells cosmetics, drinks and groceries. She is 30 years old and married with four children. She hopes to own a fashion home in the future. With her combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family.

Mercy has been in her business for six years. She is hoping for a loan of 60,000 nairas to purchase more cosmetics and hair extensions. She is a LAPO client. LAPO is a microfinance institution with a goal of alleviating poverty in the lives of the working poor in Nigeria.

Mercy is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr: Z. Rachelle est née le 23 Juin 1976 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUNKPE Sévérin un infirmier, Rachelle est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. En plus de cet enfant, Rachelle a un autre enfant en charge. Il y a trois ans que Rachelle vit avec ses enfants et son conjoint à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou. Seul le conjoint de Rachelle assure les charges de la famille. Il y a deux ans de cela que Rachelle mène comme activité, la vente de vêtements  et de sous-vêtements dans sa barraque à son domicile. Rachelle s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin ; à Comé et à Lomé au Togo. Rachelle a déjà obtenu de ALIDé, un crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’agrandir son activité pour satisfaire plus sa clientèle en ces période de préparation des fêtes,  Rachelle sollicite un deuxième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Z. Rachelle was born on June 23, 1976 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to Mr. HOUNKPE Sévérin, who is a nurse, she is the mother of one child who is attending school.  In addition, she has another child to support.  For three years, she has been living with her children and husband in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou.  Rachelle's husband is the only one ensuring that family expenses are covered.  For two years, Rachelle has been running a business selling clothing and undergarments in a stall at her house.  She supplies herself from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin; from Comé; and from Lomé, Togo. She has had an ALIDé loan before, which has been repaid.  In order to augment her working capital and to expand her business, so as to satisfy her customers further preparing for these holidays, she's requesting a second ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 4 dozen outfits with blouses and a dozen undergarments

loans.name: Haja

texts.en:
This is Haja K., a 32-year-old widow from Wilberforce (an area within Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone). Haja has two children, one boy and one girl, both of whom attend primary school. She has been a client of LAPOSL for some time now, and has taken out two previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders. 

Haja has a market stall in Freetown, from which she sells cassava, potato leaves, charcoal, and small bags of drinking water. With her first two loans, she expanded the inventory of her stall, and added charcoal to her list of items. With her new loan, Haja hopes to travel to Guinea (a neighbor country of Sierra Leone) to purchase clothing, hand bags, jewelry, and other similar goods, which she can sell from her market stall for a greater profit than the goods she sells now. Haja believes that “business must be taken stage by stage”, and she hopes her latest LAPO loan will allow her to move forward to an increased profit and a higher standard of living.

loans.use: Travelling to Guinea to purchase clothes and accessories for sale in Freetown

loans.name: Barikisu

texts.en:
Barikisu sells roasted corn in front of the education office near where she lives. She takes delivery of stock from Techiman, a market town in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She is 32 years old, married and the mother of three children. Through hard work, and with support from her husband, all of her children attend school in her community.

Barikisu requests this loan to buy stock in bulk as she believes this will help her in times of price hikes. She dreams of providing her children with a high quality of life now and as they get older. She does not want any of her children to do the business she is doing; she'd rather see them through school.

loans.use: To buy maize, peanuts, etc.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas sells tubers of yam at retail prices to her customers. She is 45 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to improve on her business. She has been in her business for a long time. She hopes to be a major yam distributor in the future. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more tubers of yam to sell. 
Dorcas says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Boubacar C. est âgé de 35 ans marié et père de deux enfants. Il habite dans une famille polygame dans le quartier Kaboïla I- Kélétiguila, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Boubacar, après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès, décide de s’installer dans le commerce de l’habillements depuis maintenant six ans.
 Vu l’augmentation de sa clientèle et que ses ressources propres ne pouvant satisfaire les attentes de cette clientèle, il  jugea utile de venir auprès de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour lui solliciter ce premier prêt individuel afin d’augmenter son fonds propre. 
Il compte acheter avec ce premier prêt, 5 paires de chaussures “Ferardine”, 3 complets de vestes “Abacos”, 4 paires de souliers, une douzaine de ceintures, 6 pantalons de qualité différentes, 8 chemises différentes etc. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (auprès des grossistes) et effectue ses ventes essentiellement de façon ambulante entre les différentes structures professionnelles étatiques et privées de la ville de Sikasso.
Ce présent prêt lui permettra de réaliser un bénéfice de 80 000 FCFA qui servira à augmenter son fonds de commerce, honorer ses engagements à l’égard de Soro Yiriwaso et couvrir d’autres dépenses familles.
texts.en:
Mr. Boubacar C. is 35 years old, married, and the father of two children. He lives in a polygamous family in the Kaboïla I- Kélétiguila district, the downtown of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run several businesses unsuccessfully, he decided to settle on commerce in clothing six years ago. Given the increase in customers and the fact his own resources are not able to meet their expectations, he thought it useful to come to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to request this first individual loan, so as to augment his own funds. He intends to use his first loan to purchase 5 pairs of “Ferardine” shoes, 3 “Abacos” suits with jackets, 4 pairs of basic shoes, a dozen belts, 6 pants of different grades, 8 different shirts, etc. He supplies himself in Bamako (from wholesalers), and he makes his sales essentially door-to-door among various professional organizations both governmental and private, in Sikasso City. The current loan will enable him to realize a profit of 80,000 francs CFA that will be used to augment his working capital, to honor his commitments with regard to Soro Yiriwaso, and to cover additional family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Née le 17 Septembre 1982 à Sikasso, Fatoumata B. est une divorcée, mère de deux garçons qui vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Médine-Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, Fatoumata B.  décida  finalement de s’initier  à l’activité d’achat et de vente d’articles d’alimentation il y a environ cinq  ans. Elle mène cette activité devant leur domicile à Médine Sikasso où elle est beaucoup  appréciée et sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant deux mois. Elle est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Avec ce premier prêt  elle compte acheter, auprès de ses fournisseurs 50 cartons d’eau minérale, 35 paquets de boisson NBB, 30 casiers de boisson BRAMALI, 20 cartons de boisson  en canette  de différentes sortes et d’autres articles. 
Elle achète ses marchandises sur place et vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée des femmes et des jeunes surtout en cette période d’approche des fêtes (Tabaski, Noël et Fin d’année). 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on September 17, 1982 in Sikasso, Fatoumata B. is divorced and the mother of two children.  She lives in a large traditional extended family in Médine-Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run many businesses without success, she decided in the end to become introduced to buying and selling food items five years ago.  She operates her business in front of her home in Médine Sikasso, where she is much appreciated by her customers for the quality of her goods. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two months ago.  She is now on her first individual loan, which she intends to use to buy from suppliers:  50 boxes of mineral water, 35 packets of NBB drinks, 30 cases of BRAMALI drinks, 20 boxes of canned drinks of various kinds, and other items.  She purchases her goods locally and sells to customers composed of women and young people, cash or credit accepted, particularly during this period leading up to the holidays (Tabaski, Christmas, and New Year).  She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the interest on her loan.  The rest will be invested into her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies (mineral water, canned beverages, containers, etc.)

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 48 years old and divorced with no children. She works hard as a petty trader selling foodstuffs like tomatoes, onions, peppers, smoked and dried fish, yams, plantains, etc. in bulk at the market. She takes delivery of goods from the surrounding villages and purchases some from Kumasi Central Market. Her problem now is inadequate business funding to make progress. With loan assistance, she believes her dream of buying more stock can be achieved. Janet would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy vegetables like onions, peppers, tomatoes, etc.

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Boré a 41 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 7 enfants, à Wayerma I, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Oumou après avoir mené beaucoup d’activité sans succès, s’initia à l’activité de restauration  apprise auprès une tante depuis maintenant quinze ans. Elle mène son activité  à Wayerma I Sikasso devant le domicile conjugal toutes les nuits. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses plats alimentaires. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq ans. Après 8 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel et tous  les prêts  précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce quatrième prêt, 26 paquets de spaghetti, 40kg de poissons frais, 40kg de haricot, 40 sachets d’Attièkè, 25 poulets, 1 sac de pomme de terre, 30kg de haricot vert et un stock de bananes plantain. 
Elle achète ses marchandises sur place et effectue ses ventes au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée des femmes, des jeunes (célibataires) surtout de noctambules. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce , contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Oumou Boré is 41 years old and lives with her husband and seven children in Wayerma I, the downtown of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After having run many businesses unsuccessfully, she got introduced to the business of food service, which she learned from an aunt, fifteen years ago.  She runs her business in Wayerma I Sikasso in front of her conjugal home every night.  She is much in demand by her customers for the quality of the dishes she serves.  To satisfy the growing number of patrons, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago.  After eight solidarity loans (group loans) with a women's association in her district, she is now on her fourth individual loan.  All the preceding loans have been properly repaid.  She intends to use this fourth loan to buy:  26 packets of spaghetti, 40 kg of fresh fish, 40 kg of beans, 40 pouches of attièkè (a couscous made of fermented cassava), 25 hens, a sack of potatoes, 30 kg of green beans, and a stock of plantains.  Supplies are purchased locally, and sales are made in cash or on credit to customers composed of women and youngsters (unmarried), especially night owls or moonlighters.  She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for augmenting her working capital, helping to cover family expenses, and paying the interest on her loan.  The rest will be invested into her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Chickens, beans, bananas, fresh fish, spaghetti, "attièkè", potatoes

loans.name: 10 De Noviembre Ii Group

texts.es:
Salomé P. por primera vez ingresa al grupo 10 de Noviembre a invitación de su tía. Ella vende abarrotes (alimento seco como arroz, fideo, harina, lenteja y otros) inició este negocio ayudando a su madre y ahora se hace cargo del mismo porque su madre falleció, Salomé necesita el préstamo para comprar arroz, ella adquiere su mercadería de Santa Cruz y vende en diferentes ferias de la ciudad de El Alto, todos los días desde las 7 de la mañana con la ayuda de su hermano.
Las demás integrantes del grupo cuentas con diferentes negocios como la costura de ropa, tejido de prendas de vestir, producción de chocolates, elaboración de pan, venta de huevo, aceite condimentos y zapatos. Estas señoras necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería y materia prima.
texts.en:
Salomé P. first joined the group "10 de Noviembre" (10th of November) after being invited by her aunt. She sells groceries (dry food like rice, noodles, flour, lentils, and other items). She started out helping her mother with this business and now she is solely in charge because her mother passed away. Salomé needs the loan to buy rice. She purchases her merchandise from Santa Cruz and sells it in different fairs in the city of El Alto everyday from 7 in the morning with the help of her brother. The rest of the members of the group work in different trades like sewing, weaving, the production of chocolates, bread making, selling eggs, oil condiments and shoes. These women need the loan in order to purchase merchandise and raw materials.

Translated from Spanish by Seton Hill University , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and raw materials

loans.name: Family Tree Group

texts.en:
James F.'s business is the sale of medical drugs. He buys drugs from pharmaceutical companies and sells retail to buyers from around Peace Island, Monrovia, Liberia. He is a high school graduate attending a vocational school studying nursing. James sells drugs that are needed by his customers and gives them affordable prices in order to encourage them to continue patronizing his business. He has been running this business for seven years and is hoping to upgrade to a shop. James started with 3,650 Liberian dollars in savings from brick molding contracts. He needs this loan to purchase more drugs to improve his business.

James is 30 years old and married with two children, ages 7 and 14, in Grades 2 and 5. He also cares for four nieces. James and his family live and work in Peace Island, Gardnerville community, north of the Liberian capital, Monrovia. James dreams of giving his family all the support they need in order to improve their living conditions.

James is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Family Tree".

loans.use: To purchase pharmaceuticals

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yaya D.  a 40 ans, marié et père de deux enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et leurs enfants dans sa propre maison à Banconi, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Après une formation de tradi-thérapeute, il s’est vite initié aux activités  d’achat et de vente de produits pharmaceutiques de la pharmacopée chinoises et autres depuis maintenant vingt ans. Avec une telle expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes, mais les ressources financières nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins font défaut. Ainsi, il sollicite ce 2ème prêt individuel auprès de Soro Yiriwaso qui lui permettra, d’acheter 4 cartons d’Aloé, 7 cartons de Manames, 8 bidons d’inzam indien, etc.  
Monsieur D. est en relation avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ 2 ans.  Le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé.  
Il  s’approvisionne auprès de son fournisseur à Koutiala pour venir les revendre à Sikasso dans sa pharmacie située à la gare routière de Sikasso à une clientèle composée des voyageurs et surtout des routiers. Certains de ses clients payent au comptant, d’autre à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yaya D., aged 40, is married and the father of two children.  He lives with his wife and their children in his own house in Banconi, one of the outlying districts of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After training in traditional healing, he quickly learned twenty years ago about the business of buying and selling pharmaceutical products and those from the Chinese pharmacopoeia and more.  With such experience in this field, he enjoys a strong reputation and accommodates many orders.  But the financial resources necessary are lacking for satisfying these needs.  Thus, he's requesting this second individual loan from Soro Yiriwaso.  This will enable him to buy 4 boxes of Aloé, 7 boxes of Manames, 8 containers of inzam indien, etc. Mr. D. has had an association with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for about two years.  The preceding loan was properly repaid.  He gets his supplies from providers in Koutiala and sells his goods in Sikasso in his pharmacy located at the Sikasso bus station.  His customers are composed of travelers and especially drivers.  Some of his customers pay in cash, others on credit.  With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA that he plans on using to take care of most of his expenses and those of his family and to pay the interest on his loan.  The rest will be invested into his business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Medicines (Aloé, Maname, Lipton, etc.)

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia sells frozen foods like chicken and fish in a cold store and also runs a grocery shop in the local market near where she lives. She is 48 years old and a married woman with six children. Three of her children are currently in school. She started her business 15 years ago. She takes delivery of stock from Kumasi in bulk to supply her customers. She does not have adequate funds to support her business. This has affected her operation, especially in the face of increasing food prices. With this loan, she wants to purchase more cartons of frozen foods like fish and chicken and grocery goods to enable her to raise enough income to expand her sales. She dreams of being the number one supplier of frozen food in her community.

loans.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken and mutton, etc.

loans.name: Evangelina

texts.es:
Evangelina es una mujer D. 46 años sencilla y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia, junto a su esposo Eleuterio D. 53 años y su hijo Rubén D. 17 años, y lo que más desea es que su familia tenga una vida feliz.

Su negocio está ubicado en una zona altamente comercial D. su ciudad y está convencida que la variedad D. sus productos incrementaran sus ventas, es por eso que se esmera mucho en no repetir modelos en la vestimenta que teje.
Lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es tejer, se divierte mucho haciéndolo y ese estado D. ánimo lo refleja en los acabados D. su trabajo, lleva 10 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus tejidos hasta su puesto D. venta, ya que los fardos pesan mucho. Para más adelante, espera poner una tienda D. tejidos artesanales muy granD., donD. pueda vender sus prendas con mayor tranquilidad.

Este es el segundo préstamo D. Evangelina con MFP y en este tiempo a descubierto la importancia D. trabajar en grupo. Ella está segura D. pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y así no causar problemas a su banco comunal, donD. es muy querida por la alegría que demuestra. Con los mil soles solicitados comprará más lana para incrementar la cantidad D. tejidos que produce.
texts.en:
Evangelina, 46, is an unassuming, hard-working woman. She lives in her own house with her husband, Eleuterio, 53, and her 17-year-old son, Rubén. Her greatest wish is that her family have a happy life. Her business is located in a highly commercial area of her city and she is convinced that the variety of her products increase her sales so she makes a special effort to keep her designs unique in the clothing she weaves. What she most likes about her work is the weaving itself; she enjoys doing it very much and her state of mind is reflected in the finishes she gives her work. She has had this occupation for 10 years. The most difficult part of the work is transporting the finished items to her sales stall because the bundles are very heavy. For further into the future, she would like to establish a large store from which to sell woven handicrafts and where she can sell her clothing items more peacefully. This is Evangelina's second loan with MFP and she has discovered the value inherent in working in a group. She is confident that she will repay her loan on time and not cause her communal bank any problems where she is very well-liked for the joy she expresses. With the two-thousand soles requested she will buy more wool to increase the number of woven items she produces.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wool.

loans.name: God's Empowerment Group

texts.en:
Louza F. is a leader of a group of 5 borrowers called God’s Empowerment. She is a 40 year old single mother of  2 children.  Her children are 15 and 19 years old and their educational levels 10th  and 12th  grade. Louza  also cares for her niece and nephew.
