To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizers to augment her production

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en: Hiba is a 33-year-old single woman living with her parents. She has owned a lingerie shop since 2008 and she is the only provider for her family. She works hard to earn a good income to help satisfy their needs. Today, Hiba is asking for a loan of $1,200 to increase her inventory in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: Increase her inventory

loans.name: Ifeyinwa

texts.en:
Ifeyinwa is 30 years old and a fashion designer. She sews very well and a lot people patronize her business. She has been in the sewing field for four years. "I love my business and I love seeing people on fine wears say Ifeyinwa," she said.

She sustains and supports her family with this business. She hopes to expand her business in the future and add sarongs and tailoring material to sell. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase sarongs and tailoring materials to sell to meet customer demand, especially during this festive period. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase sarong materials to sell

loans.name: Isa

texts.en:
Isa B. is a farmer, which is how he supports his family which consists of his wife and 7 children.

With great sacrifice he has been able to be successful and has supported himself with the loans he has received from IMON.

In spite of the economic challenges that Isa has encountered, he has been able, with much sacrifice, to support his home and that is why today he is concerned about improving his work by investing in crops through technical assistance and by buying seeds and fertilizers for their development.

Today Isa has approached IMON for a loan that will permit him to buy supplies for his crops. This loan will benefit him as well as the family that he loves so much.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Akbarali

texts.en: Akbarali is one of the most hardworking young men in the area where he lives, which differentiates him from other local residents and makes him stand out as a well-respected and very important member of his community. Farming requires a lot of effort which is why, from a young age, Akbarali has dedicated himself to this business and today is seeking a way to expand his efforts in order to support his family which consists of his wife and a little son. Because his crop provides the main income for the family, Akbarali is seeking a loan of 3,000 Somoni to plow more farmland and purchase seeds and fertilizer. The loan will allow him to expand his farming business. Akbarali hopes the loan will increase his family's income. He hopes you will support him and thanks you for your generosity. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer for sowing potatoes and onions

loans.name: Samakar Group

texts.en:
Here are Adama T., Ismail K. and Kadiatu K. of the Samakar group. They are businesspeople in the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone and they are seeking their first SMT/Kiva loan to invest in their businesses. With a loan of SLL 500,000 each, they will be able to increase their inventory and sales, and thereby obtain a better profit. Consequently, their standard of living will improve and they will be able to better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing as well as paying their school fees and medical bills. 

The leader of this group is Adama T. (who is on the left). Adama was born in the town of Magburaka about fifty years ago. She is a widow with six children. One of her children is already grown-up and the rest are attending primary or secondary schools. Adama has been a businesswoman since her childhood. She sells ground-nuts/peanuts, rice and beans; but selling ground-nuts is her main business. Adama will use this loan to buy bags of ground-nuts to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy bags of gound-nuts

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
K. Hasan is a farmer who has been working the land for the past seven years. He is 48 years old, married and has five children (there are six people in his household, including his five children and wife). He was educated through secondary school and had some formal training in farming. This has done the trick for him financially. In the upcoming season, Hasan plans to grow wheat, onions and carrots. This will require more money than he has, so he is requesting a loan of 3000 somoni to buy seeds and fertilizer for a successful harvest. The income will allow Hasan to take better care of his children's health, nourishment and schooling.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Isaac Nyame Group

texts.en:
Prince is a professional carpenter and has been in business for the last three years. He is 29 years old and married with one child. Carpentry has been his major occupation and the main source of livelihood for his family. He owns a carpentry shop where he manufactures all kinds of furniture. He says that, for lack of adequate working capital, he is not able to pre-finance most of the orders from his customers. This slows down his work because he has to wait for funds from his customers before any work can begin which often causes delays.

Prince requests a loan to enable him to procure useful working tools and furnishing materials like polish, glue, sandpaper, wood, etc., to improve his efficiency. He believes this will increase his income and ensure good living for his family. He is grateful for the assistance.

Prince is the leader of a trust bank group called "Isaac Nyame" which means "The God of Isaac". He is the one sitting in middle of the group in the photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and there is peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy tools and furnishing materials like polish, glue, sandpaper, etc.

loans.name: Emilienne

texts.fr: O. Emilienne est née le 19 Septembre 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Emilienne est mariée à GBEGAN Constant, un militaire. Le couple a deux enfants en charge, dont un est leur propre enfant et est scolarisé. Il y a trois ans déjà que Emilienne vit à Kouhounou, un quartier de Cotonou, avec son conjoint et ses enfants. Seul Constant supporte les charges de la famille. Emilienne a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Depuis cinq ans, Emilienne vend divers articles (savons, omo, conserves, sardines, lait, petit pois, tomate, piment, riz, huile végétale, sucre, etc.) à son domicile. Emilienne s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Emilienne a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et a bien remboursé la crédit. C'est pour accroître davantage son activité et la diversifier que Emilienne sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
O. Emilienne was born on September 19, 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to GBEGAN Constant, a soldier.  The couple has two children to support.  One of them is theirs and in school. For three years already, she has lived in Kouhounou, a district of Cotonou, with her husband and children.  Her husband Constant is the only one financially responsible for the family.  Emilienne attended school through the secondary level.  For five years in her home, she has been selling a variety of items (soaps, Omo, canned foods, sardines, milk, peas, tomatoes, chili peppers, rice, vegetable oil, sugar, etc.)  She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She once had an ALIDé loan, which she repaid.  To grow her business more and to diversify it, she's requesting another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods (canned foods, sugar, vegetable oil, rice)

loans.name: God Is Great Group

texts.en:
Aminata F. sells firewood and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) and has been in this type of business for ten years now. She is 43 years of age and married with three children. Aminata’s husband is a monthly wage earner and her children are attending school – one is in college and the others are in primary school II and V respectively. Aminata was born in Magburaka town. She will use this loan to buy firewood and gallons of palm oil.

Aminata (in the middle) is the leader of the "God is Great" Group. They are business people from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva for the first time seeking a loan of 1,500,000 leones (SLL) (500,000 SLL each) to invest in their businesses.

loans.use: To buy firewood and gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Shoimardon

texts.en:
Shoimardon K. is 49 years of age, married with 4 children, and lives with his family in Shahrituz, Tajikistan.

He is dedicated to agriculture, having 6 years of experience at this activity. Shoimardon has sown different kinds of vegetables and wheat. A part of his crop is destined for personal use and the majority he sells in the different markets of Shahrituz.

The income that he generates with this activity varies depending on the season in which the product is harvested. That is why his wife and elder sons support him in paying the household expenses.

The economic situation of the country has affected the acquisition of the supplies for productive work. The costs of fertilizers, supplements and insecticides have increased to the point where he needs a loan to be able to buy them.

For this reason Shoimardon is asking for a loan of 3400 TJS. You could become an important part of his family's life. Shoimardon deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Goeglino

texts.en:
Goeglino O. is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.

Goeglino would like to get a loan to purchase additional groceries. She is planning to purchase a variety of groceries and will significantly expand her groceries business.

Goeglino is 38 years old, married and has four children. She is married to Mr. O. who is a farmer. Her children are doing well in school. She is a committed LAPO client.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 50 years old. He is married and the father of seven children. All his children are in school. His first daughter is in nursing school and the rest are in senior, junior and elementary school respectively.

Joseph works very hard to provide for the educational needs of his children. He trades in furniture woods. He takes stock of wood from the big sawmills and supplies the carpenters in his community.

Joseph says wood is becoming very expensive and now he cannot procure large quantities.

He requests loan assistance to enable him buy more form the market so that he can make a profit and pay for his children’s education. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of wood.

loans.name: Zafarjon

texts.en:
Zafarjon S. is 37 years old, married and has 6 children. He has a secondary education and has an animal husbandry business. He has a small cow house where he breeds calves.

Because he does not have a specialized education, animal husbandry is the only source of income for his family. Zafarjon buys calves on the market at a low price, feeds them, and then resells them on the same market at a more profitable price. He provides the markets with meat and his family with the necessary food.

Zafarjon wants to buy more cattle and needs money so he decided to apply for a loan of 1500 USD.

Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro entrepreneur, and his experience in the business, this customer is qualified to receive this loan.

Your support will really help him. Zafarjon is counting on your help.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expanding her arable land and buying farm supplies

loans.name: Bénédicta

texts.fr: A. Bénédicta est née le 29 Janvier 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à GNAHLODJEZO Ignace un agent du Trésor au Bénin, Bénédicta est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Bénédicta vit depuis trois ans avec ses enfants au quartier Houéyiho à Cotonou. Bénédicta a été à l'école jusqu'à l'Université. Pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Bénédicta vend des tissus par le système de distribution. Bénédicta s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Bénédicta a déjà trois ans d'expérience dans ce métier et est à son deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Bénédicta a bien remboursé son premier crédit. Afin d'accroître son étalage et de fidéliser sa clientèle, Bénédicta sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Bénédicta A. was born on January 29, 1972, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She's married to Ignace GNAHLODJEZO, an employee of the Ministry of Finance. She's the mother of two school-attending children. Bénédicta has been living for three years with her children in the Houéyiho neighborhood in Cotonou. She went to school up to the university. To support her children, Bénédicata sells fabrics by the distribution system. She gets her supplies in Lomé in Togo, a neighboring state of Benin. She already has three years' experience in this job and is seeking her second loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé. She repaid her first loan without problems. In order to expand her stall and win the loyalty of her customers, she's seeking another loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pieces of fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To renovate her business place

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer and expand her acreage

loans.name: Good Family Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Good Family Group who are all small-scale businesspeople in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan from SMT/Kiva for the first time. Each is requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 to improve his or her business and consequently to improve his or her standard of living.

Ibrahim C. in the middle of the photo is the leader of this group. He was born in Magburaka town about thirty-seven years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have four children. One of his children is in Junior Secondary School I and the others are in primary school III and V; the youngest is not of school going age.

Ibrahim sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), beans and rice. He has been in this business for over ten years now. He will invest this loan in his business by buying more gallons of palm-oil and bags of beans and rice.

loans.use: To buy gallons of palm-oil and bags of rice and beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shoes in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To equip his workshop, buy lumber and work tool

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: A. Philomène est née en 1966 à Djidja, un village du Bénin. Mariée à AKOUTE Nicolas, Philomène est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés, dont seulement un est à sa charge. Philomène vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son conjoint au quartier Vêdoko à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis environs 8 ans. Seul Nicolas assure les dépenses de la famille. Philomène a très tôt abandonné l'école et depuis près de 22 ans, elle exerce le métier de la couture. A côté de cela, Philomène vend des tissus dans son atelier situé à Zogbo, un quartier de Cotonou. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà obtenu quatre crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Afin d'agrandir davantage son activité et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Philomène sollicite un cinquième crédit de ALIDé. Philomène ambitionne acquérir des matériels plus performants pour son atelier de couture.
texts.en:
A. Philomène was born in 1966 in Djidja, a village in Benin.  Married to AKOUTE Nicolas, she is the mother of four children who are all in school.  Only one of these children is in her care.  For about eight years, she has been living with her children and husband in the Vêdoko district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Nicolas alone ensures that family expenses are covered.  Early on, Philomène dropped out of school.  For 22 years, she has been working at sewing as a trade.  Aside from this, she sells fabrics in her workshop located in Zogbo, a district in Cotonou.  She is a previous ALIDé client who has already had four loans, which have been repaid.  To expand her business more and to satisfy her customers further, she's requesting a fifth ALIDé loan.  Her ambition is to acquire more efficient equipment for her sewing shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts of cloth ("Tchigan", "Tchivi", "bazin")

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: renovating her business place

loans.name: Elvisse

texts.pt:
Elvis absalome M. nasceu no Distrito de Chibuto, província de Gaza, tem 27 anos de idade, casado e pai de 4 filhos de 4, 3, 2, e 1 anos de idade, ainda sem idade escolar. Nunca frequentou escola. Vive na casa própria em Boane com a sua família e sustenta mais 4 pessoas que vivem com na mesma casa.

Saiu de Chibuto para Maputo durante a guerra, como forma de se refugiar, acabou ficando em Boane ate hoje. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 15 anos onde trabalha juntamente com a sua esposa das 8h as 22h. Esta actividade aprendeu na Republica da Africa do Sul quando esteve empregado numa loja. Vende mais bebidas alcoólicas e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 1.000.00mt por dia. Poupa algum mensalmente na sua conta do Banco comercial Millennium Bim.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outras instituições de crédito, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua sogra que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt, com o qual pretende adquirir produtos para o seu negócio (cerveja, vinhos, refrescos e produtos de 1ª necessidade) como forma de responder a demanda de seus clientes. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.500.00mt e 15.000.00mt, ambos para a mesma actividade.

Tem como objectivo, aumentar o volume de sua mercadoria, consequentemente o aumento também do seu rendimento. 
No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para construir a sua casa e mobiliário.
texts.en:
Elvisse Absalome M. was born in the district of Chibuto in the province of Gaza. He is 27, married, and the father of 4 children. His chidren are 4, 3, 2, and 1, so they still aren't of school age. Elvisse never went to school. He lives in his own home in Boane with his family and supports 4 more people who live in his house as well. He left Chibuto for Maputo during the war as a way to find refuge. He ended up staying in Boane until now. He has had his own business for more than 15 years, where he works along with his wife from 8 a.m. until 10 p.m. He learned this work in South Africa when he was employed in a store. He sells alcoholic beverages and makes an income of around 1,000 meticais per day. He puts away savings every month in his account in the Millennium Bim bank. He has never had a loan with another credit institution. He became familiar with Hluvuku through his mother-in-law, who is also a client with this institution. This is his third loan, and it is in the amount of 20,000 meticais. He will use it to acquire products for his business (beer, wine, soft drinks, and basic goods) as a way to respond to his customers' demands. His previous loans were for 6,500 and 15,000 meticais, both for the same purpose. He has a goal of increasing his merchandise so he can consequently increase his income. In the future, he would like to request more loans to construct his house and to furnish it.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying and selling alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and other items

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
These are members of the United Sisters Group. They are small scale businesspeople in the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT for the first time to seek a loan of SLL 2,500,000 (SLL 500,000 each) to boost their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make better profits and consequently improve their living standards.

Kama B. is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka town. She is approximately age twenty-seven and is married with two children, one of whom is in class VI and the other is not of school going age. Her husband is a monthly wage earner.

Kama sells rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), garden eggs (eggplant) and other market food. She has been a businesswoman for ten years now. With this loan, Kama will travel to makeshift business centers (luma centers) to buy bags of rice, gallons of palm-oil and bags of garden eggs.

loans.use: To buy rice, palm-oil and garden eggs

loans.name: Deolinda Celestino

texts.pt:
Deolinda Celestino B. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Província de Maputo, separada e mãe de 3 filhos de 13, 10 e 4 anos de idade, os mais velhos vão a escola. Fez 10ª classe, mais tarde continuou com a formação de professores, no Instituto de Magistério Primário da Matola. Vive na casa própria com os seus filhos e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Nunca mudou da cidade onde vive, após da sua separação continuou a residir com os seus filhos, trabalha como professora, quadro do Ministério da Educação, aufere um salário de 7.600.00mt por mes. Com a ajuda do subsídio enviado mensalmente pelo pai dos filhos, consegue alimentar a família e poupar algum valor na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus colegas e este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 20.500.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (aros de portas, janelas, cimento e outros) para melhorar a sua residência. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de todos para a mesma actividade.

Pretende solicitar mais empréstimos no futuro, para poder concluir com a sua obra, compra de mobiliário e oferecer melhores condições de habitação para os seus filhos.
texts.en:
Deolinda Celestino B. was born in the city of Matola in the province of Maputo. She is separated and the mother of 3 three children, who are 13, 10, and 4. The oldest ones go to school. She studied through 10th grade and later continued studying to be a teacher in the Instituto de Magistério Primário in Matola. She lives in her own home with her children and doesn't support anyone else besides them. She never moved from the city where she lives. After her separation, she continued living with her children, and she works as a teacher for the Ministry of Education. She earns a salary of 7,600 meticais per month. With the help of a subsidy that the father of her children sends her every month, she feeds her family and saves some in her bank account. She has never had a loan with another bank. She became familiar with Hluvuku through her colleagues, and this is her 3rd loan. It is for 20,500 meticais and she will use it to buy construction materials (doors, windows, cement, etc.) to improve her home. Her previous loans were also used for this purpose. She hopes to request more loans in the future to be able to finish her home, to buy furniture, and to offer better living conditions to her children.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, doors, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock up on beans, flour, and oil

loans.name: Clara

texts.en: Clara sells groceries: powdered milk, tea, etc. She is married and has eight children. She has been in business for about 22 years and she enjoys doing it. With the profit from her business, she has been able to send her children to school and they are doing well. Clara is a faithful client in one of the unions in LAPO. She was successful with her first Kiva loan, which she has finished repaying. She wants to expand her business and improve on her sales. In order to do this, she is requesting a second loan of 50,000 nairas.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk

loans.name: Canan

texts.en:
Canan A. is currently in the business of selling beer in a bar and is requesting a loan to buy more crates of beer. She is 42 years old and widowed; she has 7 children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and the empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchasing more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Adama J. (right) is a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon in Magburaka town. She is 27 years old and single with one child who is in class I. Adama was born in Magburaka town. She has been in her profession for ten years now. She will invest her share of the loan in hair and cosmetics.

Adama is the leader of the United Sisters Group. They are small-scale business people from Magburaka town, Northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 1,500,000 leones (SLL) (500,000 SLL each) for the first time to to expand and improve their businesses. With more goods in their shops/stalls, they will be able to attract a lot of customers, make more sales and increase their profit margin. Consequently, they will be able to better look after themselves and their children.

loans.use: To buy hair and cosmetics

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en:
Sunday C. brews and sells beer locally. She is requesting a loan to purchase more materials to use. Sunday is 30 years old and widowed. She has 6 children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and the empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchasing more materials with which to brew beer

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her projects in business. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She would like to get a loan of N 150,000 to purchase more groceries for sale. Felicia is 29 years old and married to Mr. O., who is a commercial bike rider. She is an LAPO client. She says thanks you to all lenders for the support.

loans.use: purchasing more groceries to sell

loans.name: Maryserah

texts.en:
Maryserah is a 26 year old married mother of two. She runs a dairy in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has been in this business for three years and previously ran a salon, which she closed because it was not financially stable. Maryserah earns extra income selling potatoes. Her husband is employed as a security guard.  

She is requesting a loan for 20,000 Kenyan shillings, which she will use along with some savings to buy: buckets and a gauge for 4,000 shillings, coolant for 6,000 shillings, and a counter for 15,000 shillings. She hopes to expand the business into a wholesale supplier, getting milk direct from farmers, and also to revive her salon along with a training school for salon workers. She describes herself as hardworking, capable, and able to exploit any opportunity.

loans.use: To buy equipment for her business

loans.name: Hortencia Fabiao

texts.pt:
Hortencia Fabião S. nasceu no Distrito de Manjacaze, na Província de Gaza, tem 37 anos de idade, casada mãe de 5 filhos de 17, 11, 08, 04, e 1 anos de idade, os mais velhos vão a escola. Fez 6ª classe, na altura não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras pelos progenitores, este ano voltou e frequenta a 7 ª classe. Vive na casa própria com a sua família, sustenta os sobrinhos que vivem com ela.

 Após o casamento saiu de Manjacaze para Maputo em 1998 com o seu marido, que trabalha na Direcção Nacional de Estradas como fiscal. É comerciante e dona do seu próprio negocio há mais de 3 anos. Não tem empregados apenas tem recebido ajuda dos filhos. Nesta actividade consegue um rendimento de 500.00mt por dia, com a ajuda do salário do marido que aufere 10.698.78mt consegue poupar no banco comercial BARCLAYS.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da amiga, Maria Ndlate que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de Zinco e barrotes) para proceder com a cobertura da sua obra. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 9.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt, ambos para a mesma actividade.

Depois da cobertura da sua casa, deseja solicitar mais empréstimos, para terminar esta obra assim como mobilar a casa.
texts.en:
Hortencia Fabião S. was born in the district of Manjacaze in the province of Gaza. She is 37; married; and has 5 children who are 17, 11, 8, 4, and 1. The oldest ones go to school. She studied through 6th grade and had to stop going to school due to her parents' lack of financial resources. This year she returned to school and is going to the 7th grade. She lives in her own home with her family. She also supports her nieces and/or nephews who live with her. After she got married, she left Manjacaze for Maputo in 1998 with her husband, who works at the National Road Directive as an inspector. She is a merchant and has owned her own business for more than 3 years. She doesn't have employees and only has the help of two of her children. From this business, she receives a daily profit of 500 meticais. With the help of the salary of her husband, which is 10,698 meticais a month, she manages to save some in the Barclays bank. She hasn't had a loan at other banks. She became familiar with Hluvuku through her friend, Maria Ndlate, who is also a client of the institution. This is her third loan, and it is for 15,000 meticais. She will use it to purchase construction materials (metal sheets and bars) to continue putting a roof on her home. Her previous loans were for 9,000 and 10,000 meticais, which were both used for the same purpose. After she puts a roof on her home, she hopes to request more loans to finish her house and to furnish it.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction material (cement, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Celestino

texts.pt:
Celestino Manuel Guerra Nhanjoba nasceu na cidade de Tete, Província do mesmo nome, tem 55 anos de idade, casado e pai de 5 filhos de 14, 12, 10, 8 e 3 anos de idade, destes os 4 mais velhos vão a escola. Fez 4º ano de faculdade de medicina na Rússia nos anos de 1974 a 1981 ate altura do seu regresso. Vive numa casa própria com a sua família, não sustenta mais ninguém. 

Saiu de Tete para Rússia em 1974, quando teve bolsa de estudos para dar continuidade com a formação que esteve a seguir em Moçambique. Regressa em 1981, começa a trabalhar no Ministério da Saúde ate a sua reforma em 2004. Tem um negocio próprio que desenvolve com a ajuda da esposa que vende fardos de roupa usada diversa compra a 12.300.00mt o fardo e vende a 16.000.00mt. Tem um salário de 3.900.00mt, uma pensão de 8.187.00 e cerca de 7.000.00 a 9.000.00mt por mes, provenientes do seu negocio e poupa algum mensalmente na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus amigos que também são clientes desta instituição a muito tempo. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo na instituição no valor de 20.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar mais produtos para o seu negócio (fardos diversos de roupa) como forma de aumentar e diversificar o seu produto.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente o seu empréstimo, para poder aceder a mais empréstimos no futuro e ampliar ainda mais o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Celestino Manuel Guerra Nhanjoba was born in the city of Tete, in the province with the same name. He is 55; married; and is the father of 5 children who are 14, 12, 10, 8, and 3. The four oldest go to school. He studied through his fourth year of medicine in Russia from 1974-1981 and then moved back to Mozambique. He lives in his own home with his family and doesn't support anyone besides them. He left Tete for Russia in 1974, where he had a scholarship to continue studying. He returned in 1981 and began to work at the Ministry of Health until his retirement in 2004. He has his own business, which he runs with the help of his wife. He sells bundles of various used clothing. He buys them for 12,000 meticais per bundle and sells them for 16,000 meticais. He has a monthly salary of 3,900 meticais and a pension of 8,187 a month. He saves some money every month in his bank account from the profits from his business. He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through his friends who have been clients of the institution for a long time. This is his first loan and it is for 20,000 meticais. He will use it to buy more products for his business (various bundles of clothing) as a way to diversify his products. He promises to pay back his loan on time so he can request more loans in the future to keep expanding his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase used clothing

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is married with two children. He runs a shop selling household goods in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. He also earns some extra income through small-scale farming. He is requesting a loan for 30,000 Kenyan shillings to increase his inventory of sugar, wheat flour, and rice.

In the future, Paul hopes to own more livestock to enable more farming and to become a wholesale supplier of household goods. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: Add to stock of sugar, wheat flour, & rice

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica is 43 years old, married, and has five children who are doing well in school. She has been selling foodstuffs for over seven years, supporting her husband who is a motor repairer. Veronica is a very hard working woman, she intends to increase her sales by purchasing more foodstuffs in bulk and making more profit. Her major challenge is finding funding to keep up with demand. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira.  Veronica has been in LAPO for eight years with a good record. She thanks Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food for resale

loans.name: Leonor Elija

texts.pt:
Leonor Elija C. nasceu no Distrito de Chibuto, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 51 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 3 filhos de 35, 32 e 25 anos de idade, ninguém vai a escola. Não estudou porque na altura os pais não dispunham de condições financeiras favoráveis. Vive na casa própria com a família e sustenta mais 2 netos que vivem com ela.

Saiu da Província de Gaza para Maputo anos de 1987, após a morte do presidente Samora Machel, a procura de melhores condições de vida, tendo depois construído uma residência no bairro 5 em Boane na Província de Maputo. Tem um negócio próprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade a mais de 3 anos, também é médica tradicional (curandeira). Nestas actividades consegue um rendimento mensal de cerca de 5.000.00mt que aplica no sustento da família e poupa algum por mes, através do sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma amiga e este é o seu 7º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar produtos de mercearia (arroz, óleo, açúcar, amendoim e outros) para poder responder a demanda do mercado. Os empréstimos anteriores foram (quatro de 15.000,00mt, 1 de 10.000,00mt, 1 de 5.000,00mt e 1 de 2.500,00mt para as actividades de comércio e habitação.

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos, para construir uma mercearia de material convencional, como forma de garantir segurança e higiene nos seus produtos.
texts.en:
Leonor Elija C. was born in the district of Chibuto in the province of Gaza in southern Mozambique. She is 51; single, and the mother of 3 children who are 35, 32, and 25. None of them goes to school. She didn't go to school because her parents didn't have the financial resources to send her. She lives in her own home with her family and also supports 2 grandchildren who live with her. She left the province of Gaza for Maputo in 1987 in search of better living conditions after the death of president Samora Machel. Afterwards, she constructed her home in neighborhood 5 in Boane in the province of Maputo. She has had her own business selling basic goods for more than 3 years. She also practices traditional medicine, which is known as curandeira. With these activities, she make a monthly profit of 5,000 meticais, which she uses to support her family. She also saves some every month through a traditional rotating savings program. She has never had a loan with another insitution. She became familiar with Hluvuku through a friend. This is her 7th loan, and it is for 15,000 meticais. She will use it purchase merchandise (rice, margarine, sugar, peanuts, etc.) to respond to market demand. Her previous loans ( 4 for 15,000 meticais, 1 for 10,000 meticais, 1 for 5,000 meticais, and 1 for 2,500 meticais) went towards her business and housing needs. In the future, she hopes to request more loans to construct a shelter of conventional materials as a way of guaranteeing the safety and freshness of her products.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell various food products

loans.name: United We Stand Group

texts.en:
Mark K. is a leader of a group of 5 borrowers called United We Stand. He is 24 years old, a single father of a 3 year-old child who is in kindergarten.  He is an 11th grade student but also runs a business.  

Mark lives and work in the Waterside community, a community that has the largest wholesale market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  His business is the sale of T-shirts.  He buys them at wholesale and sells them at retail in the Waterside Market, downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  He has been running this business for 9 years, and hopes to improve it in the future.  Mark sells quality T-shirts in high demand to encourage his customers to continue buying from him.  He needs this loan to purchase more t-shirts to improve business.  Mark dreams of having a better education.

loans.use: To purchase more t-shirts for resale

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is 42 years old, divorced, and has a ten year old son named Allan. He is a carpenter who makes furniture. He has been in business for twelve years and employs three casual workers. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase timber for furniture.

Thomas describes himself as friendly and a leader and would like to expand his business and have a big workshop, possibly moving into an industrial area at a prime location. He says that since joining Faulu, he has been helped to save.

loans.use: Add stock of timber

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials in bulk

loans.name: Sunday Group

texts.en:
Sunday W. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called the Sunday Group. He is 57 years old, married and has five children, aged between 15 and 35 years old. Their educational levels are between 3rd grade and university student. Sunday and his family live and work in the Westpoint community, close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Sunday has never been to school. He started fishing when he was a child, and has been running a fishing business for 30 years. He fishes in a small canoe on the Atlantic Ocean, and sell to retailers in Westpoint, Monrovia. Sunday talks to his customers well in order to encourage them to continue buying from him. He is requesting a loan to expand his business. He dreams of giving his children a better education and good health.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: A. Christine est née le 12 Novembre 1979. C'est une célibataire sans enfant, qui vit depuis trois ans au quartier Houéyiho à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Christine a été à l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Christine vit seule, et pour subvenir à ses besoins, elle vend divers articles (savons, omo, lait, allumettes, bougies, huile d'arachide, etc.) et aussi des paires de chaussures à son domicile. Christine a déjà 4 ans d'expérience dans ce domaine. Christine fait ses approvisionnements à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Christine a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Pour augmenter son capital et son étalage afin de mieux rentabiliser son activité, Christine sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Christine was born on November 12, 1979. She is unmarried and without children and has been living for three years in the Houéyiho district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has completed secondary school. She lives alone, and to support herself, she sells a variety of goods (soaps, Omo, milk, matches, candles, peanut oil, etc.) and also shoes, out of her home. Christine already has four years of experience in this domain. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and from Lomé in Togo, a country neighboring Benin. She obtained an ALIDé loan before, which she has repaid. To augment her capital and her display of goods, so as to make her business more profitable, she's requesting another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes and various goods (soaps, canned foods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fish in bulk for her business

loans.name: Scholastica

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 42-year-old Scholastica K. from Tukuyu. She is married with four children between the ages of 9 and 19. In addition, she is responsible for supporting two dependants because they are orphans.

Scholastica has been purchasing and selling clothes since 2003. She works at her business for between nine and twelve hours per day, six days per week. She currently earns about $100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to open the same business at a new location. Scholastica thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania through microleasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk

loans.name: Eni

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Eni M. from Tukuyu. She is married with five children between the ages of 8 and 19.

Eni has been running a local restaurant business since 2005. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough, wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot, sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked, savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. Eni works at the business for between nine and twelve hours per day, seven days per week, and currently earns about $90 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to improve the quality of her business premises. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Eni thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania through microleasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To improve the quality of her business premises

loans.name: Fanice Imali

texts.en:
Fanice is 51 years old and widowed with one son. She sells cereals, rice, beans, millet, soya beans, cassava, sorghum, and groundnuts to walk-in customers and local residents. She has been running her business for the last 18 years and it has helped her to care for her family and educate her son. Fanice describes herself as respectful and attentive to her customers' needs. Her main business challenges are insecurity leading to her goods being stolen at night, destruction of her goods by the rains, and the poor road transport network for distributing her goods.

Fanice is requesting a loan of 85,000 KES to buy cereals, maize, beans and groundnuts. In the future, she wants to expand her business, build a permanent stall, and own a hotel.

loans.use: To buy cereals, maize, beans and groundnuts

loans.name: Hannah Group

texts.en:
Hannah C. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called the Hannah Group. She is 35 years old, married and has four children aged between four and twelve years old. Their educational levels are between kindergarten and fourth grade. Hannah is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to poverty. She and her family live and work in the West Point community, close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Hannah has had a dry fish business for ten years. She buys fish from fishermen, dries the fish, and sells them to the residents of West Point, Monrovia. She sells good fish and talks to her customers in a nice manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.

Hannah is requesting this loan to purchase more fish to improve her business. Her dream is that her children have a better education and that she is able to attend to their health.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to improve business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more soap, rice, salt, and cooking oil in bulk

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel O. a 36-year-old father of three sons. He owns Gussy Enterprises and sells cedar poles for fencing. The poles are used by constructors and homebuilders to fence off a construction/building site. He believes he has a role to play in society by creating employment to the needy. Currently he has two employees and hopes to increase as his business expands. 

His business challenges are the chaos and fracas in the area and the long distance he has to travel to obtain cedar poles. He is using the proceeds of an 80,000 Kenyan shillings loan to buy more of the cedar posts.  In the future, he wants to expand his business and sell timber for making furniture. Gabriel  describes himself as honest, hardworking and faithful.

loans.use: To buy more cedar poles used for fencing

loans.name: Achraf

texts.en:
Achraf is a 29-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their four children. Achraf has been working as a furniture painter for almost two years. Achraf requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase some tools and a car for his work. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

Achraf is special in his work because he has a lot of skills and always does nice and precise work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had some financial issues. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work related to his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase some tools and a car for his work

loans.name: Cecelia Group

texts.en:
Juliana M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called the Akosombo group. She is 35 years old and married with two children, who are 2 and 8 and in kindergarten and 2nd grade. She is a 10th-grade dropout due to poverty, but decided to get into business. Juliana lives and works in the West Point community, close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of clothes. She buys clothes from wholesalers and sells retail to residents of West Point. She has been running this business for eight years and hopes to improve business in the future.

Juliana sells quality clothes and talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. She needs this loan to purchase more clothes to improve business. Juaina dreams of giving her children a better education.

loans.use: She needs this loan to purchase more clothes to improve business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk for her business

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Abel

texts.es:
Abel A. B. es un señor de 52 años de edad que vive con su esposa y sus tres hijos en una comunidad llamada Cimarrón de Santa Teresita de Turrialba, Provincia de Cartago.  Es una pequeña comunidad rural de aproximadamente dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y la agricultura. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. Cimarrón se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano. Sin embargo, varias veces al año el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias.

Don Abel se dedica a la producción de leche y en estos momentos desea obtener un microcrédito por ¢500.000(quinientos mil colones) para comprar una vaca lechera más y así aumentar la producción. El sabe que contar con una vaca más es un mayor sacrificio y demandará más trabajo pero dice que si quiere sacar su familia adelante tiene que esforzarse en producir más.

Él ordeña en un local que acondicionó para tal fin y dice que por día logra producir aproximadamente 80 litros de leche y con una vaca más su producción aumentaría a 100 litros diarios por lo cual esta muy emocionado de poder ver como su negocio crece y se fortalece.

Don Abel es socio de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Nuevas Esperanzas para Cimarrón, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su segundo préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Abel A. B., 52, lives with his wife and their three children in a community called Cimarrón de Santa Teresita de Turrialba in the Cartago province. It is a small, rural community with approximately 2,000 inhabitants. The population works in milk production and farming. The landscape is irregular, and much of the land is humid tropical rain forest. Cimarrón is located approximately one and a half hours by bus from Turrialba, the closest commercial center. However, several times a year the road becomes impassable because of the rains. Abel is a milk producer. At this time he wishes to get a loan for ¢500.000 (five hundred thousand colones) to buy one more dairy cow to increase production. He knows that having another cow is a big sacrifice, and that it will demand more work. He says that if he wants to get his family ahead, he needs to make the effort to produce more. He does his work in a place equipped to milk. He says that he produces approximately 80 liters of milk a day. With an additional cow his production would increase to 100 liters daily. That is why he is very excited to be able to see how his business grows and gets stronger. Abel is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal Nuevas Esperanzas para Cimarrón (the New Hope for Cimmarón Communal Bank), one of the 100 member organizations of Edesa in Costa Rica. This will be his second loan. With the loan he hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level. He will also actively participate in the credit organization in his community.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start a new clothes business.

loans.name: Silas Ambei

texts.en: Silas Ambei, 30 years old, owns the Tumaini Traders. He sells sugar, cooking oil, rice, tealeaves, sodas, brakes fluid, baking flour and bicycle spares to the local customers and motorbike operators in the area. He has been in this business for the past three years. In addition, Silas also raises poultry. His business challenges are strong competition and fluctuation in the price of goods. He is using the proceeds of KES 80,000 to increase his stock of household goods. In future, he wants to be the best stocked wholesaler in his area. Silas is married to a nurse and he describes himself as a pastor and a serious man to his creditors.

loans.use: To buy household goods.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional stock of red palm seeds and to pay for transportation.

loans.name: Basel

texts.en:
Basel is a 37-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their three children. Basel has operated a butcher shop since 1999. Basel is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase livestock for his work. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

Basel is speciA. in his work because he runs a clean shop. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work and he had experience in the area. In the future, he plans on expanding his business by having his own livestock.

loans.use: To purchase livestock for his work.

loans.name: Najla

texts.en:
Najla is a 57-year-old woman who lives in the Bekaa with her husband. Najla has owned a grocery store since 1985. She also sells fruits and vegetables. Najla has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is the first time that Najla has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. 

Najla is successful in her business because she knows how to treat her clients. In addition, she has a good reputation. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have a lot of merchandise. Najla decided to open her store initially to supplement her husband’s income. In the future, she plans to expand her business by selling wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma R. V. es una señora de 40 años de edad quien vive con sus dos hijos y su pequeña hija en una comunidad llamada Canalete localizada en Upala en la provincia de Alajuela, es un lugar semimontañoso y sus actividades económicas se centran en la agricultura y mayormente en la ganadería. Es una comunidad con una gran oportunidad de desarrollo y establecimiento de microempresas, tanto de agroindustria como  comercio

Doña Vilma tiene cuatro años de tener su propio negocio exactamente una  pulpería (tiendita de abarrotes) ahí vende productos básicos a sus vecinos; con este negocio ha logrado tener  una actividad económica rentable que ya que es la única fuente de ingresos que tiene y la ha ayudado a mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.

Actualmente ella necesita un préstamo por ¢600.000(seiscientos mil colones) para comprar más mercadería y así surtir el inventario. Específicamente comprará abarrotes básicos como arroz, frijoles, verduras, productos enlatados, refrescos, jabón, golosinas y todo lo que se refiere a la canasta básica del costarricense que vive en las zonas rurales. Doña Vilma comenta que el servicio que ella brinda es muy importante ya que no existen otra pulpería muy cerca de la zona  por lo tanto tiene bastantes clientes. 

Doña Vilma es socia  de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Canalete, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Vilma is a 40-year-old woman who lives with her 2 boys and 1 small girl in a community called Canalete, located in Upala, Alajuela province. This is a semi-mountainous area and its economic activities focus on agriculture and, principally, cattle ranching. The community offers great opportunities to develop and establish micro-enterprises in both agro-industry and commerce.

Vilma has had her own business, a small grocery store, for 4 years. She sells basic products to her neighbors. The store has proven to be profitable and it's the only source of income she has. It has helped improve her family's quality of life.

At present, she needs a loan of 600,000 colons to buy more merchandise and increase her inventory. Specifically, she wants to buy basics such as rice, beans, vegetables, canned goods, soft drinks, soap, sweets, and all that may be found in the rural Costa Rican's basic basket. Vilma comments that the service she offers is very important since no other grocery store exists in the zone and as a result, she has many customers.

Vilma is a member of the Canalete Community Credit Enterprise, one of the 100 organizations belonging to EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan and she hopes to continue growing at the personal and economic level, as well as to participate actively in the credit organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MERCHANDISE FOR HER GROCERY STORE
